description: From Middle English manifold, from Old English maniġfeald (“manifold, various, varied, complicated, numerous, abundant, plural”), from Proto-Germanic *managafalþaz, equivalent to many +‎ -fold. Cognate with Middle High German manecvalt (“manifold”), Icelandic margfaldr (“multiple”). Compare also German mannigfaltig (“various”), Dutch menigvoudig (“various”), Danish mangefold (“multiple”), Swedish mångfald (“diversity”).

adjectives.description: manifold (comparative more manifold, superlative most manifold)

entries.meaning: Various in kind or quality; diverse.
examples: The manifold meanings of the simple English word set are infamous among dictionary makers.

entries.meaning: Many in number, numerous; multiple, multiplied.
Exhibited at diverse times or in various ways.

adverbs.description: manifold (comparative more manifold, superlative most manifold)

entries.meaning: (historical) A copy made by the manifold writing process.
(mechanics) A pipe fitting or similar device that connects multiple inputs or outputs.
(US, dialectal, chiefly in the plural) The third stomach of a ruminant animal, an omasum.
examples: My conjecture being right he will find the third stomach, or manifolds, the seat of difficulty.

entries.meaning:
(mathematics) A topological space that looks locally like the "ordinary" Euclidean space 
  
    
      
        
          
            R
          
          
            n
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \mathbb {R} ^{n}}
  
 and is Hausdorff.
(computer graphics) A polygon mesh representing the continuous, closed surface of a solid object

description: From Middle English manifolden, from Old English maniġfealdan (“to multiply, abound, increase, extend, reward”), equivalent to many +‎ -fold. Cognate with Middle High German manecvalten, Icelandic margfalda (“to multiply”), Swedish mångfaldiga (“to manifold, reproduce”).

verbs.description: manifold (third-person singular simple present manifolds, present participle manifolding, simple past and past participle manifolded)

entries.meaning: (transitive, printing) To multiply or reproduce impressions of by a single operation.
